definition:
Equitable matrices have been used in economics and group theory [@eves].

An $n\times n$ matrix $M=(m_{ij})$ is an *equitable matrix* if all
$m_{ij}$ are positive, and $m_{ij}=m_{ik} m_{kj}$ for all
$i,j,k=1,\ldots, n$.

Setting $i=j=k$ yields $m_{ii}=m_{ii} m_{ii}$ so diagonal elements of
equitable matrices equal $1$. Next, setting $i=j$ yields
$m_{ii}=m_{ik} m_{ki}$, so $m_{ik} =1/m_{ki}$.

### Examples {#examples .unnumbered}

1.  An example of an equitable matrix of order $n$ is
    $$\begin{pmatrix} 1 & \cdots & 1 \\
                      \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\
                      1 & \cdots & 1 \end{pmatrix}.$$ This example shows
    that equitable matrices exist for all $n$.

2.  The most general equitable matrix of orders $2$ and $3$ are
    $$\begin{pmatrix} 1 & a \\
                      1/a & 1 \end{pmatrix},$$ and
    $$\begin{pmatrix} 1 & a & ab  \\
                      1/a & 1 &b \\
                      1/ab & 1/b & 1 \end{pmatrix},$$ where $a,b,c>0$.

### Properties {#properties .unnumbered}

1.  A $n \times n$ matrix $M=(m_{ij})$ is equitable if and only if it
    can be expressed in the form
    $$m_{ij} = \exp (\lambda_i - \lambda_j)$$ for real numbers
    $\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \ldots, \lambda_n$ with $\lambda_1 = 0$. ()

2.  An equitable matrix is completely determined by its first row. If
    $m_{1i}$, $i=1, \ldots, n$ are known, then
    $$m_{ij} = \frac{m_{1j}}{m_{1i}}.$$

3.  If $M$ is an $n\times n$ equitable matrix, then
    $$\operatorname{exp}(M) = I + \frac{e^n-1}{n} M,$$ where
    $\operatorname{exp}$ is the matrix exponential.

4.  Equitable matrices form a group under the Hadamard product [@eves].

5.  If $M$ is an $n\times n$ equitable matrix and
    $s\colon \{1,\ldots, r\}\to \{1, \ldots, n\}$ is a mapping, then
    $$K_{ab} = M_{s(a)\, s(b)}, \quad a,b=1,\ldots, r$$ is an equitable
    $r\times r$ matrix. In particular, striking the $l$:th row and
    column in an equitable matrix yields a new equitable matrix.

See [@eves] for further properties and references.

[9]{} H. Eves, *Elementary Matrix Theory*, Dover publications, 1980.
